description: Sub-dividing site and erection of 2 x bedrooms 2 storey dwelling.Sub-dividing site and erection of 2 x bedrooms 2 storey dwelling.
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to above groundworks (excluding demolition) of the development hereby permitted and notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans stated in condition 2 of this permission, the following details shall have been submitted (on plans at a scale of no less than 1 :20 and 1 :5) and approved by the Local Planning Authority.- Window reveals, door reveals, overhangs, rainwater goods.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved detailsReason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising fromdevelopment works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any trees, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the siteduring the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.0) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(I) Hours of construction and deliveriesReason: This information is required prior to the commencement of the development as the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The garage or car parking accommodation shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development hereby permitted the applicant shall submit details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development to be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and they shall be fully implemented in accordance with the approved details and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Fences, walls or other means of enclosure shall be erected along the boundaries of the site prior to the occupation of the dwelling houses to which they relate, in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and shall thereafter be permanently retained.Reason: In order to ensure the privacy of adjoining occupiers and visual amenity of the area is retained in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential units hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has achieved an energy efficiency standard of a minimum of 19% C02 improvement over Building Regulations requirements Part L 2013 (TER Baseline).Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential units hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has achieved as a minimum, a water efficiency standard of not more than 110 litres per person per day maximum water consumption in accordance with the requirements defined within Approved Document G of the Building Regulations.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development a landscaping scheme including the detail of the removal of any trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved drawings the applicant shall submit full details of refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities to the Local Planning Authority prior to the occupation of the development and the details shall be approved in writing and implemented in accordance with the approved details and, thereafter such facilities shall be permanently retained at the site.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the use of the building commencing and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build and that the principles of sustainable drainage are incorporated into this proposal and maintained for the lifetime of the proposal, in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
E4 - Acoustic Conditions in Schools
A1 - Loading

SiteThe application relates to a first floor flat situated within a two-storey semi-detached property located on Lingfield Avenue. The site is within a Controlled Parking Zone as well as the Cranes Park Local Area of Special Character. Planning HistoryNo relevant planning history. Consultations17 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 representations were received OBJECTING to the application on the grounds of:Loss of sunlight Loss of privacyExcessive height or bulk of buildingsInappropriate design/layoutThe points raised in relation to the impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse and area, as well as on the amenity of neighbouring properties are material planning concerns and will be discussed in the consideration of this recommendation.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a flat roof dormer extension to the rear/side roofslope. Whilst the proposed dormer extension would not strictly conform to the recommendations of the Residential Design SPD, and would arguably not relate well to the existing roof form of the application site, Officers note that the proposed dormer extension would not dominate the rear roof slope. Furthermore, as it would be sited to the rear roofslope, it would not be visible from the streetscene. As such, Officers consider that the proposed dormer extension would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse. The application also proposes the installation of one window on the front elevation of the property, 2 no. rooflights to the front roofslope and 1 no. rooflight to the rear roofslope. These additions are considered appropriate to the dwellinghouse, and would not detract from its character. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are No. 24, the ground floor flat at No. 26 Lingfield Avenue and No. 28 Lingfield Avenue. In relation to both No. 24 and No. 28 Lingfield Avenue, due to the siting of the proposed extension, its scale and that no windows are proposed facing these neighbouring properties, Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in a unacceptable impact on amenity through loss of sunlight, privacy or an overbearing appearance. In relation to the ground floor flat at No. 26 Lingfield Avenue, due to the scale and siting of the proposed development in relation to this neighbouring property in conjunction with the positioning of the application site in relation to the path of the sun, Officers consider that the proposal would not result in a significant loss of sunlight. Furthermore, due to the scale and siting of the proposed development, the development would not result in an overbearing appearance. Moreover, whilst the application proposes to install a new window facing the garden of this neighbouring property, as the view from this window would not be too dissimilar from the view of the existing windows at first floor level, Officers consider that the proposal would not result in a significantly unacceptable loss of privacy to this neighbouring property. To the rear of the site are the properties Nos. 31-35 Cranes Park Avenue. Whilst the proposal would introduce a new window at second floor level facing these neighbouring properties, as the proposed development would be situated over 40 metres away from these neighbouring properties, Officers are satisfied that the proposed development would not result in a significant loss of privacy through overlooking. As such, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. Officers Comments: The Cranes Park Local Area of Special Character constitutes a non-designated heritage asset. As it is considered that the proposed development would result in an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse, Officers consider that the proposed development would also not harm the cultural significance of the non-designated heritage asset, the Cranes Park Local Area of Special Character.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultees and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 7 (Landscaping) of planning permission 21/01891/FUL, which states:Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, a hard and soft landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey mid-terrace dwellinghouse located on George Road. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Planning History09/14761/LDP - Loft conversion with rear dormers. Application Granted on 15 Jan 2010.513/MC/2 - Bathroom and WC. Application Granted on 08 Mar 1949513/MC/1 - Bathroom and WC. Application Granted on 08 Mar 1949Consultations8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 representation was received OBJECTING to the application on the grounds of:Excessive height or bulk of buildingsLoss of light/SunlightEncroaching on neighbouring landParty wall issuesOverbearing impactThe points raised in relation to the impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse/area, as well as the impact on the amenity of neighbouring properties are material planning concerns and will be discussed in the consideration of this recommendation. In relation to the issues raised in relation to the party wall, this is a civil matter related to the Party Wall Act and not a planning concern and as such will not be discussed within the consideration of this recommendation. Finally, in relation to the points raised regarding the encroachment onto neighbouring land, this application has been amended and the proposed extension would now set back from the shared boundary with the neighbouring property at No. 8 and as such will no longer encroach on this land. ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: Whilst the proposed single storey side/rear extension would not strictly adhere to the guidance of the Residential Design SPD, extending approximately 5.7 metres beyond the rear wall of the existing dwellinghouse, given the existing extensions to the dwellinghouse and similar extensions at neighbouring properties, Officers consider that the proposed would not be an uncharacteristic form of development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposals to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments:  The principal properties to consider in relation to Amenity are No. 6 and No. 10 George Road.In relation to No. 6 George Road, this neighbouring property benefits from a single storey rear extension, and an overhanging roof. Whilst the proposed development would extend further than this neighbouring extensions, due to the scale of the proposed development in conjunction with the existing neighbouring extension, Officers consider that the proposal would not result in a significantly unacceptable loss of light or an overbearing appearance to this neighbouring property. Furthermore, as no windows are proposed facing this neighbouring property, the application would not result in a loss of privacy to No. 6 George Road.  In relation to No. 10 George Road, the application has been amended to be set back from the boundary of this neighbouring property by approximately 150mm, and the height of the eaves of the extension on the boundary of this neighbouring property has been reduced to approximately 2.7 metres. As such, when taking into consideration the reduced height and set back from the boundary, Officers consider that the proposal would not result in an overbearing appearance to No. 10 George Road.   In relation to the impact on sunlight, No. 10 George Road benefits from a window on the rear elevation of the property in close proximity to the proposed development. When taking a 45 degree line from the centre of this window on the floor plans provided, this line would intersect the proposed development. However, when taking a 45 degree line from the centre of this window on the elevations drawings provided, it would not intersect the proposed development. As such, whilst the proposed development may result in some loss of sunlight to this neighbouring habitable room window, Officers consider it would not be to an unacceptable level. Furthermore, the provided Solar Analysis supports this conclusion due to the positioning of windows on this neighbouring property, in relation to the proposed development and positioning of the sun throughout the day.  Finally, as no windows are proposed facing this neighbouring property, the proposal would not result in a loss of privacy. The proposed development would therefore have an acceptable impact on the amenity of neighbouring properties. London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.The representations that have been received have been carefully consdiered, however, on balance, Officers concluded that the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 5 (Secure Cycle Storage) of planning permission 21/01891/FUL, which states:Prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 10 (Drainage Design Strategy) of Planning Permission ref: 18/10413/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
Condition 10 (Drainage Design Strategy) -  Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Conditions 4 (Flood voids and grilles), 17 (Drainage maintanance plan) and 26 (Vehicular access/Footway) of planning permission 19/02368/FUL are hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 3 (Materials) of planning permission 17/15107/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Ellerton Road. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Planning History15/16156/HOU - Erection of a single storey side rear infill extension. Application Granted on 21 Apr 2015. With conditions. (Does not appear to have been implemented).Consultations9 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension which would measure approximately 6 metres in depth from the rear wall of the dwellinghouse. The extension would have a dual-pitched roof and would measure a maximum of 4 metres in height. Whilst the proposed extension would far exceed the recommended depth as outlined by the Residential Design SPD, in relation to the dwellinghouse in conjunction with existing extensions, Officers would still consider that the proposed extension would appear proportionate and subordinate. There would be no adverse impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
Condition 3 (Materials) Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.
The proposed ground floor plan shows 'Edge Fence 2400 height (for privacy)'. Please confirm the application includes erection of fence or not. Please submit the drawings of fence as necessary.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Conversion of existing garage into habitable space, erection of part two storey/part single storey side, single storey front and rear patio extension. Hip to gable roof alteration, installation of 1 no front rooflignt and erection of single storey rear outbuilding.'

We do not accept land registry location plan. Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

Please provide a Proposed Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Demolition of existing rear conservatory and erection of a single storey rear extension.'
Please provide the existing and proposed floor plans if there area any changes in floor.

The submitted elevations are not labelled as existing or proposed. Please provide copies of all existing and proposed elevations with correct labelling at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Over sheeting of the existing profiled metal roofs on several terraced units (Units 18-24, 42-44, 60-62). Increase in roof height and alteration to elevations.'If you do not agree with the description, please amend it in your own words.

The application form describes the proposed development as 'Provision of thermal insulation externally and rendering to flank wall' however, the proposed drawings include the erection of roof extensions. Please confirm the exact nature of the proposal being applied for. If the roof extensions do not form part of this application then please omit this from the drawings. If however, you wish to include them then please confirm. If so, we shall amend the description to include the roof extensions.

The scale bar in the submitted block plan does not measute to the stated scale. Please provide a Proposed Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
